sn7.7:1.2: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Pure went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn7.7:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn7.7:1.4: and recited this verse in his presence:
sn7.7:2.1: “No brahmin in the world is ever purified
sn7.7:2.2: even though he’s ethical and mortifies himself.
sn7.7:2.3: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct
sn7.7:3.3: if they’re filthy and corrupt within,
sn7.7:4.1: Regardless of whether you’re an aristocrat,
sn7.7:4.2: a brahmin, merchant, worker, <j>or an outcaste or scavenger—
sn7.7:4.6: Know that for a fact, brahmin.”
sn7.7:5.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Pure said to the Buddha,
sn7.7:5.3: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.
